tweet: (6/6) To learn more about the SNAP program, check out our fact sheet.  https://www.jec.senate.gov/public/_cache/files/d657a411-2fd3-4570-b352-ff86ab54aa16/supplemental-nutrition-assistance-program---jec.pdf …

(5/6) Work requirements instituted in 1996 make the program less effective. Research shows the restrictions do little to encourage employment and significantly reduce the # of people who use the SNAP program. This undermines SNAP’s effectiveness as an automatic stabilizer.

(4/6) SNAP is an automatic stabilizer, meaning it kicks in during a recession w/o the need for new legislation. SNAP enrollment and benefits rise when workers lose their jobs, helping low-income families sustain food spending and keeping the economy from slowing more severely. pic.twitter.com/PJOx4JVNqN

(3/6) SNAP also promotes consumer spending & cushions the economy during recessions. Because SNAP beneficiaries typically spend all of their benefits, the money goes directly into the economy. It’s estimated that for every $1B billion the govt spends on SNAP, GDP rises by $1.54B.

(2/6) SNAP reduces food insecurity for families and has long-term effects on the health & economic stability of children. A 2016 study showed that children who gained access to SNAP benefits either in utero or in early childhood were healthier as adults.

(1/6) #OTD in '64 LBJ signed the Food Stamp Act, which was later renamed SNAP and has become America’s most effective anti-hunger program. Tens of millions get help from SNAP, with children, the elderly & people with a disability accounting for the majority of beneficiaries. pic.twitter.com/T9EKlejk1u

This is the kind of market manipulation that would get corporate executives sent to prison. And it hurts the President's credibility with investors, which could come back to haunt the economy during a downturn or financial crisis. #Trump https://www.vanityfair.com/news/2019/08/donald-trump-china-call-fake …

NEW: Personal income grew just 0.1% in July, far short of analyst estimates and below the 0.6% increase in consumer spending, according to @BEA_News. Wages rose 0.2% after climbing 0.5% in June. https://www.cnbc.com/2019/08/30/us-consumer-spending-increases-solidly-income-tepid.html …

Meanwhile, the trade deficit in goods was $72.3 billion in July, down from $74.2 billion in June, @uscensusbureau reported this morning. Exports grew in July while imports shrank.  https://www.census.gov/econ/indicators/advance_report.pdf …

According to a story by @jeffkearns, the downward revision reflects lower estimates for exports, inventories, residential investment & state/local govt spending. The report suggests "trade actions are weighing more heavily on the pace of expansion." https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2019-08-29/u-s-second-quarter-growth-revised-down-to-2-pace-from-2-1?srnd=economics-vp …

Initial takeaway: consumer & federal spending offset shrinking investments & exports. According to today's report, personal consumption grew 4.7% and federal expenditures & investments rose 8.1%. Private domestic investment fell 6.1% and net exports were down 5.8%.

BREAKING: Second-quarter GDP growth revised down to 2.0% from 2.1%, according to @BEA_News' second estimate.  https://www.bea.gov/news/2019/gross-domestic-product-2nd-quarter-2019-second-estimate-corporate-profits-2nd-quarter … pic.twitter.com/NyklwvVv0z
GDP (2nd estimate) and trade-balance reports due out soon...stay tuned!! pic.twitter.com/e68xiD7b3H

(6/6) 56 years after the March on Washington, black children experience far less upward mobility than white children. For every 100 black children who grow up in households in the bottom 5th of the income distribution, less than 3 will make it to the top 5th as adults.

(5/6) Disparities also persist in income levels. The median income for black households was about $28,000 less than their white counterparts in 2017. While the white median household income reached a new high in 2017, the black median was still below its peak in 2000.

(4/6) But racial disparities persist. Black unemployment peaked at 16.8% after the Great Recession, before falling to 7.7% at the end of the Obama Administration and 6.0% in July. That’s almost twice the current white unemployment rate. pic.twitter.com/ewvq59iF2R
(3/6) And according to @blackenterprise, the top 100 black-owned businesses generated over $26 billion in revenue in 2017.
(2/6) The black community accounted for $1.2 trillion in consumer spending in 2017—a number that’s expected to reach $1.5 trillion by 2021. #IHaveADream #MarchOnWashington

(1/6) Today marks the 56th anniversary of the March on Washington & the 64th anniversary of Emmett Till’s murder, which many agree was the catalyst to the Civil Rights Movement. Since the 50s & 60s, the black community has made amazing economic progress, though challenges remain. pic.twitter.com/HN0vL8i4gt

The fight for women’s equality didn’t end in 1920. Policies like Paid Family and Medical Leave and the Paycheck Fairness Act are needed to continue the progress towards equality. #WomensEqualityDay 9/9

...One study shows that mothers are the sole or primary breadwinners in half of U.S. households with children.  https://iwpr.org/wp-content/uploads/wpallimport/files/iwpr-export/publications/Q054.pdf … 8.5/9
The gender pay gap has large impacts on families and the economy—women’s share of household earnings has grown from 36 percent in 1993 to 45 percent in 2016...8/9
...Economists often point to this large, unexplained portion of the gender pay gap as possible evidence of labor market discrimination.  http://www.nber.org/papers/w21913.pdf …   7.5/9

One influential study shows that after accounting for gender differences in education, experience, industry and occupation, about 38 percent of the gender pay gap is due to factors that cannot be measured...7/9

Many women experience what is called the“child penalty”—decreased earnings after interrupting their careers to have and care for children.These wage penalties have a cumulative impact on their income and professional experiencesthroughout their career.  https://iwpr.org/women-earn-just-half-of-what-men-earn-over-15-years/ … 6/9

Women are often underrepresented in higher-paying fields, such as many types of science, technology, engineering, and math (STEM) jobs. Women occupy just 14 percent of engineering and 25 percent of computer science jobs.   https://www.pewresearch.org/fact-tank/2018/01/09/7-facts-about-the-stem-workforce/ … 5/9

Women are overrepresented in lower-paying fields. According to a study looking at 2016 data, women made up nearly two-thirds of the roughly 24 million workers in low-wage jobs, yet they accounted for slightly less than half of the overall workforce.  https://nwlc-ciw49tixgw5lbab.stackpathdns.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/04/Low-Wage-Jobs-Held-Primarily-by-Women-Will-Grow-the-Most-Over-the-Next-Decade-2018.pdf … 4/9
The gap is much wider among women of color: black and Hispanic women earned 61 cents and 53 cents respectively for every dollar earned by white men in 2017. 3/9

Even though women now earn the majority of advanced degrees in the United States, women are typically paid 80 cents for each dollar paid to men, and the gap is largest among men and women with advanced degrees.  https://www.wsj.com/articles/historic-rise-of-college-educated-women-in-labor-force-changes-workplace-11566303223 … 2/9 pic.twitter.com/MLliBzT4Li
Happy #WomensEqualityDay, the day we celebrate women winning the right to vote in 1920. While women now legally have equal access to the ballot box, they still do not receive equal pay 1/9

Recent research by economists @nhendren82 and @bsprungkeyser finds anti-poverty programs that invest in child health and education pay for themselves in the long run. It’s critical we continue to fund and expand programs that give families and children a decent shot. (4/4)

Despite the gains made from LBJ’s War on Poverty, 40 mil Americans still live in poverty today. Child poverty alone costs our economy $1T a year in health care costs, higher crime rates, lost wages. Yet the Trump administration falsely claims that the War on Poverty is over (2/4)

As Vice Chair @RepMaloney put it after publishing today's report, "It is particularly important to protect and strengthen Social Security, while recognizing that the rest of our retirement system is in crisis." https://www.jec.senate.gov/public/index.cfm/democrats/press-releases?ID=C1EB92D7-4F08-47DF-A521-F2C9DE672C0D …

While #SocialSecurity does prevent millions from falling into poverty when they retire, many others are vulnerable. For example, women’s lower earnings in retirement combine with their relatively long life spans to create a risk of outliving their savings.  https://www.jec.senate.gov/public/_cache/files/0fddd609-a00d-44da-aba8-cd15357010d9/retirement-insecurity-jec.pdf … pic.twitter.com/3ghVl3IPkn

And while all groups benefit from Social Security, women, minorities and low-earners replace a larger share of their career incomes from the program because of its progressive benefit structure. pic.twitter.com/jHaIrZ8MQJ

Meanwhile nearly half of all seniors get a majority of their retirement income from Social Security, and one fifth are almost completely reliant on the program. These are workers who have been unable to save enough for retirement... pic.twitter.com/y9u344Vxsr

In the @JECDems report today, Retirement Insecurity, we show that half of American households run the risk of being unable to maintain their standard of living in retirement.  Even those who take extra steps—like working until 65—may have to cut back.  https://www.jec.senate.gov/public/_cache/files/0fddd609-a00d-44da-aba8-cd15357010d9/retirement-insecurity-jec.pdf … pic.twitter.com/VDnXjEQNBL

Yet more must be done, as @RepMaloney notes in a new report by @JECDems. "Despite Social Security’s success, the other two major components of our nation’s retirement system – private savings and pensions – are failing hardworking Americans." See why here:  https://www.jec.senate.gov/public/_cache/files/0fddd609-a00d-44da-aba8-cd15357010d9/retirement-insecurity-jec.pdf … pic.twitter.com/jfsHTnS763

84 years ago today, President Franklin Roosevelt signed the law creating #SocialSecurity, to help protect elderly Americans against poverty in the midst of the Great Depression. It has become the bedrock of America's #retirement security. pic.twitter.com/3OoeMEIWoz

Check out Vice Chair @RepMaloney's op-ed on #SocialSecurity & retirement in today's @NYDailyNews: "On this anniversary of Social Security, it’s crucial to protect and strengthen the program...Americans deserve a retirement system that works for everyone." https://www.nydailynews.com/opinion/ny-oped-social-security-20190814-zxv4iz2lyng3lninrmluco2ofy-story.html …

“As a result, roughly half of Americans are at risk of losing their current standard of living in retirement…These problems are particularly acute for women, minorities and people with low earnings or less education.”  https://www.jec.senate.gov/public/_cache/files/0fddd609-a00d-44da-aba8-cd15357010d9/retirement-insecurity-jec.pdf …

On SocialSecurity's 84th anniversary, we're publishing a report called Retirement Insecurity. According to Vice Chair @RepMaloney, “Despite Social Security’s success, the other two major components of our nation’s retirement system – private savings and pensions – are failing..."

Today, Social Security continues to protect Americans when the other two parts of the “three-legged stool” of retirement – private savings and pensions – are inadequate. https://twitter.com/CapitolHistory/status/1161634659727544320 …

FDR on #SocialSecurity: “We have tried to frame a law which will give some measure of protection to the average citizen and to his family against the loss of a job and against poverty-ridden old age.” pic.twitter.com/Teyx7eCZhY

The climate crisis is real and has real economic costs in addition to the human and environmental toll. @JECDems addressed the issue in depth in our response to the Economic Report of the President:  https://www.jec.senate.gov/public/_cache/files/23f52103-aecc-409a-9b12-71dd0b95bbb2/climate-crisis-chapter.pdf … https://twitter.com/emma_newburger/status/1159452316233322496 …

Federal funding for research on gun violence faces severe restrictions, making it hard to study what's behind the crisis. Federal agencies provided just $22M to research gun violence from 2004-2015, far less than research into other causes of death.  https://twitter.com/davidfrum/status/1158157625441312768 … pic.twitter.com/v0GlvAQ6di

(5/5) What’s more, the @CBO estimates the GOP tax cuts will cost $1.9 trillion through 2029—nearly 2x what it would cost to fix and update the nation’s water infrastructure, according to the American Water Works Association.  http://www.climateneeds.umd.edu/reports/American-Water-Works.pdf …

(4/5) Clean-water laws have done a lot to protect Americans, and a recent @nberpub analysis shows the health benefits of investing in drinking water exceed the costs. And yet the Trump administration has weakened restrictions on polluting waterways.  https://www.nber.org/papers/w26077.pdf …

(3/5) This isn’t only in Flint—Reuters has found nearly 3,000 areas in the United States with lead poisoning rates at least double those of Flint at its peak crisis. https://www.reuters.com/investigates/special-report/usa-lead-testing/ …

(2/5) Toxins in drinking water like lead can lead to health, cognitive and behavioral problems in children. In addition to the harm to the children themselves, childhood lead poisoning can cost the economy nearly $51B a year in lost productivity.
 https://www.healthaffairs.org/doi/full/10.1377/hlthaff.2010.1239 …

(1/5) Let’s talk water. Today marks 4 years since the passage of the Drinking Water Protection Act. Clean drinking water is crucial not only for public health, but also the economy. pic.twitter.com/qRcSXU3KdC

The lack of federal information on the causes of gun violence also allows policymakers to hypothesize about solutions that may not be supported by actual data. This prevents an informed debate from taking place and further
polarizes the issue.
And without federal data on gun violence, it is impossible to take local prevention programs that work and scale them up to function on a nationwide basis.

Federal funding to research gun violence is very low compared to spending on research of other leading causes of death. A 2017 study found that the federal government spends $63 on research for every life lost to gun violence, compared to nearly $183K on every HIV-related death. pic.twitter.com/a1a2gZMVog

NEW: The trade deficit in goods & services shrank by $200M to 55.2B in June amid declining imports and exports, @BEA_News & @uscensusbureau reported. The deficit in goods with China rose to $30.2B. https://www.wsj.com/articles/china-lost-spot-as-top-u-s-trading-partner-in-first-half-11564749251?mod=hp_lead_pos2 …

.@RepMaloney said “today’s report reveals persistent inequalities...” This from @BLS_gov:
• Black unemployment is 6.0%; Hispanic 4.5%; white 3.3%; Asian 2.8%
• Involuntary part-time workers total 4M
• Labor force participation among women is below men & pre-recession levels

JEC Vice Chair @RepMaloney on the #JobsReport: “I am pleased to see that employers continue to hire at a solid pace as part of the longest U.S. economic recovery on record. The economy has withstood President Trump’s erratic policies..." https://www.jec.senate.gov/public/index.cfm/democrats/press-releases?ID=7CA803E4-FFD2-4E86-92D2-1591F7A21A94 …

Manufacturing has slowed in recent months amid Trump’s trade wars, which is reflected in today’s #JobsReport. Factories added 16K workers in July, down from the monthly average of 22K last year, while the average workweek for factory employees fell.

Also of note in today’s #JobsReport:
• @BLS_gov revised its June and May job creation numbers down by a combined 41K to 193K and 62K respectively
• That puts the three-month average increase at 140K

BREAKING: The @BLS_gov #JobsReport for July is out. Key details here:
• Nonfarm payroll employment grew by 164K
• Unemployment was unchanged at 3.7%
• Wage growth picked up to 3.2% from last year
• Labor force participation rate little changed at 63%
Stay tuned for our coverage of the @BLS_gov jobs report for July, which is just minutes away. #JobsDay
